title: Patch Chat with the Playtest Team - 7.23
body:
https://i.imgur.com/38Xzv7U.jpg
Image by xmoonlitxdreamx

Hey everyone and welcome to the Patch 7.23, the ZOE PATCH!  

I’m Riot Novalas & I’m a QA Analyst on Riot’s Playtest Team, a group of high elo players who work on Core Gameplay playing new champions, reworks, balance tweaks, items, and map updates before they’re released. It’s our job to test the changes that our designers come up with and ensure that we’re introducing positive changes to League in terms of both balance and fun. 

Patch Chat serves as an opportunity for us to talk about the patches that come out every two weeks. You can find the most recent patch by following this link: 
https://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/patch/patch-723-notes

The latest black licorice champion in League of Legends hits the rift! Say hello to Zoe, the Aspect of Twilight! Our team has been assisting with Zoe for awhile so feel free to ask any questions, specifically to penguin and King Cobra as they’re the primary playtesters for her! 

Accompanying Zoe, we’re also buffing Gragas and Taliyah, nerfing Shyvana, nerfing Summon Aery, buffing Predator, and more!

Ask us anything about Zoe, our favorite rune builds on YOUR favorite champions, our favorite pair of socks (please) , how often we execute to jungle camps, and more!... Or feel free to just chat with us! We like people (mostly).

Disclaimer: We don’t have any insight into skins.

well fudge, I missed the Q&A by a good 15 hours.

But if any of ya'll are still up for chatting, can we talk about veigar for a bit?

Presently veig's ult deals a wide spectrum of damage, from 300-600 dmg early game to a whopping 900-1800 dmg late game, thus making knowing _exactly_ how much damage his ult will do to individual targets _extremely_ frustrating to calculate on the fly. And when it's veigar's job to eliminate a single target as quickly and efficiently as possible, it becomes difficult to do so, as most time the veigar player will either waste a lot of potential damage on his ult or run the risk of not killing the target at all.

I understand the point of execution abilities, but when a champ's end game fantasy is pressing the delete button on a single champ.

Long story short, can we see about getting visual indicators for when a target can be killed by a veig ult? (soz for the rush, had to go earlier than planned)

So personally I dislike visual indicators that say to the player USE THIS ABILITY TO KILL THIS TARGET (Looking at you Cho'gath!). Understanding how much your execute (i.e. Veigar or Urgot ult) can do is something that players should learn to get a feel for and be rewarded for using successfully. I'm no designer, but I think having these types of visual indicators lowers the skill cap of a lot of these champions and makes them feel less satisfying to play.

That is great to hear, though Futures Market does make him feel much better in some departments. Having E upgrade at 1250 gold just felt like such a struggle before. He definitely still has some problems though.

Future's Market is definitely powerful on champions that are looking to hit specific item breakpoints. Not just Viktor, but also Catalyst/Tiamat/Cinder champions really like it to hit their spike more reliably earlier in the game. Agreed Viktor still has some problems though.

I don't think I've ever seen anyone run that rune as anything other than a meme TBH. The simple fact is that you can just get those items by managing your gold and back times better and run a more useful rune instead.

While I do agree that there are many situations where Future's Market isn't great, it's not always true that you can just "get those items by managing your gold and back times better." It enables a lot of very precise strategies that involve tight timings that wouldn't otherwise be possible, such as Warwick backing two camps early to get Tiamat - meaning he doesn't have to do Raptors or Krugs to _get_ his Tiamat, so he can do them at a vastly increased speed after that purchase. It also allows Ivern to base early and buy boots only having smited one camp, meaning he can get level 4 at 3:08 or 3:17 (depending on which clear he's doing) with boots rather than with Faerie Charm (which is the only reasonable purchase on that clear without Future's Market). Ryze can back a wave early to get his Tear, Kassadin can reliably hit his Catalyst, and so on. 

Most of these interactions take substantial planning and foresight to use, so I expect to see them crop up more in competitive play than I do in soloqueue. Future's Market is very invisible power that's hard to see or feel, so it's not surprising to me that most players don't think it's strong, especially when it's also inconsistent power in most cases.

How does Mordekaiser feel to play?

Soooooo
I checked over the last 2 Seasons all of you combined have only played 6 games with Morde.
  So I don't expect you to answer any questions seeing as you clearly don't care

Every playtester has more than one account. In fact, we noted that we didn't have much collective experience on Mordekaiser ~2 months ago and put in a bunch of games to increase mastery. I personally put in the most games, playing 34 games in total across multiple different accounts. We do care about every champion, and we're constantly working to make sure we have appropriate knowledge coverage across the entire champion roster.

As far as your actual question, I'd say Mordekaiser feels a bit different on Runes. Before Runes went live I typically ran DFT Mordekaiser top and had a lot of success with that, though I did see some success with Stormraider's as well. On Runes Reforged I don't feel there's a good replacement for DFT (Comet doesn't seem as impactful to me for Morde), so I've run Phase Rush in every game I've played him and it feels relatively similar to Stormraider's Morde was before Runes Reforged although a bit less good early on and much better mid-late. Not needing to actually do a lot of damage to trigger the movespeed boost means it's easier to get away with lower damage builds (I typically prefer Rylai's+Liandry's -> full tank), but it does reward less for higher damage/burst builds like Gunblade. 

Overall feeling on Morde is that he's a lane-dominant juggernaut that has higher highs and lower lows than other similar champions (e.g. Illaoi, Darius). Both Illaoi and Darius have meaningful ways to contribute while behind and/or without committing their bodies to a fight, whereas Mordekaiser doesn't really have those options.

That's a sound assessment and I'd like to share a bit of my own insight on preseason Mordekaiser.

I personally always preferred SRS over DFT for the sheer combat mobility it provided and how easy it made sticking to some champions.
Now with preseason Phase Rush replaced SRS and it is in fact better late game, mostly due to the slow resistance and how reliable it is to proc with simple E, R and Gunblade.

I've been performing really well with him, using a standard Hybrid bruiser build {{item:3146}} {{item:3151}} {{item:3053}} {{item:3135}}  {{item:3078}} /{{item:3065}}

In terms of overall performance and the amount of people always asking you guys on your thoughts on Morde, I do believe a lot of people just aren't used to mordekaiser and are somewhat uninformed about him. He does have a bad reputation for being "bugged" and "bad" despite him being one of the strongest laners with monstrous snowballing potential and ways to turn a losing game into a win with his ultimate.

But yes, he always suffered from a lack of fallback patterns when he's not doing too well due to poor baseline durability and lack of utility.
I do suggest moving away from the Rylais/Liandries+Tank combo though as it falls off like a brick late game and does not make good use of his strong AP/Ad ratios and his durability being heavily linked to how much damage he can dish out.

Thoughts about attack speed slows? I get why they exist, but especially against champs like Malph who not only have an innate ability but also like to stack AS slowing items, it feels ridiculous trying to fight them as any auto based champ, especially melees like Trynd or Yasuo.

Ideally attack speed slows would be a kind of safety valve for attack speed based builds/champions. There's multiple reasons that many attack speed slows have been reduced or removed over time (Nasus W reduced, Darius W removed, Frozen Heart reduced), but there's also reasons for them to be in the game. In some cases attack speed slows give champions a specific niche they can play to (for example, Nasus' matchups into AS-based champions are stronger because of his W, which doesn't affect many other matchups - this is part of what makes him better as a toplaner than as a jungler). 

Overall I think attack speed slows feel worse than they are (in terms of raw power), but there are other similar mechanics in the game like silence and grounding that can still do good things in the right spot. In my opinion (note this is just my personal opinion, not the opinion of a designer or Live Gameplay or anything) I'd prefer it if attack speed slows were less frequent than they are now and perhaps a bit lower overall, but I think it's good for the game for certain safety valves to exist like Frozen Heart.

Do you guys feel that the buffs to Camille on the PBE at present will do enough to bring her power up to an appropriate place? (A .5 sec increase to the amount of time her true damage is available and .5 second increase to her passive shield duration)

Both will feel good, I'm sure, but I'm wondering if it will be enough to get her to where she used to be, especially with the nerf to Press the Attack going up along side it.

Camille is a tough case because of how much disconnect there is for her between experienced and inexperienced play. She's one of the top champions in the game in terms of winrate going up over games played, and she's also very strong in competitive play, so buffing her for the majority of the playerbase without overbuffing her experienced/competitive play is a hard ask. The goal with these changes is that it helps her out across the board but mostly buffs less experienced players, as her highly experienced winrate right now isn't bad, it's her overall performance that's in the gutter. That's why these changes are relatively conservative even though her overall winrate is quite poor.

On Press the Attack - based both on my personal experience and on internal data, Press the Attack is not Camille's optimal keystone. Phase Rush is seeing significantly more success and even other keystones outside Precision like Aery are outperforming PtA, which indicates to me that when people switch off PtA (or PtA becomes more usable for Camille, whichever comes first) Camille will probably see more overall success. 

All told I'm not sure these buffs will be enough for Camille to feel good for most players, but we'll see. She feels pretty strong to me with these changes in but I have >100 games on her so that's not unexpected.

I love that champ, and I wish she was more accessible. I just die waiting 1.5 seconds or accidentally hit a minion for like 500 true damage. 

Have you tried Aftershock on her? I used it in ARAM, and it felt really strong with Trinity + Sterak's + Titanic.

I've tried Aftershock, and I think it just puts too much weight into hitting E. E is already a lot of base damage, a stun, and an attack speed steroid if you hit it, and the punishment is already high if you miss - taking Aftershock feels like a win-more keystone where it only helps you when you're already doing well (hitting people with E in a position where you can stick around afterwards). Having health as a set bonus also isn't the best - for Camille above almost all other champions she wants to have kill threat if the jungler comes since her gank assist is so powerful, so it's easier to take offensive runes and itemize defensively early than it is to take defensive runes and itemize offensively since her early offensive itemization isn't great in bad matchups (doesn't have a lot of longswords in early build path for those matchups since you don't want to go Tiamat, and Sheen is a 1050g spike that's hard to get to early on). 

In ARAM I think Aftershock is probably decent since she never gets a chance to 1v1 anyone and it's a lot easier to hit random Es, so it fits well.

Thanks for the answer! I know this isn't Endstep's Camille 101 Guide, but I'll ask anyway because I love this champ...

I understand Camille pretty well. The main problem I have is landing E and all the micro around a minion wave. For example, if I'm Katarina, I can hold the "target champion only" key for Shunpo, and I automatically get an aa reset.

If I'm Camille, a minion can shift in front of E, and I lose the stun and aspd bonus. There's no aa input on E, so you have to hit A after landing, and autos don't work with the "target champ only" function. 

So you have a chance to miss E. A chance to misstarget the first Qaa. A chance to attack a minion when moving after first Q, since there's no move input without a built-in attack command. Then another chance to miss second Qaa. While timing aa resets, using an active item, and risking creep block.

Compared to champs like Fiora or Irelia, that's a lot of inputs in a really short window surrounded by a bunch of moving hitboxes, and you have to execute them in succession with 100% accuracy to duel anything. Is there some trick to making Camille a bit more foolproof, or is completely perfect micro actually her intended skill floor?

Hitting minions with E doesn't remove the possibility of getting the attackspeed/stun. All you have to do is hit a champion, and Camille's E2 only stops on hitting champions, not minions, so you can go through minions to hit champions and still get the full benefit of the ability. Holding "target champ only" won't do anything since Camille E is a skillshot, but you shouldn't have any problems with minions causing you to lose the stun/AS bonus. If you do have clips of that let me know and I can forward them over to someone who can take a look into what's causing it, though I've never heard of that being an issue before.

As far as "is Camille's skillfloor at perfect micro," I'd say no - I don't think it's a lot to ask people not to hit minions with multiple abilities in a short window. She's definitely a lot more complex to play than someone like Jax or Irelia (after all, she is one of the most difficult champions to play by all metrics I know of), but the tight timing/relative high barrier of execution on EQAAQ is not what makes her so much harder in my opinion. I'd say her positioning as one of the weakest (perhaps the weakest) laning bruisers on top of being forced into double damage items, making her very easy to punish for any mistakes is a large part of what makes her difficult. In addition to that, she has a lot of counterintuitive optimization decisions (for example, almost all bruisers max their primary damage tool first, which for Camille is Q, but E max is almost always superior), requires a huge amount of matchup knowledge (as most bruisers do) to perform in lane, and has many small nuances with each ability to optimize usage (level scaling on Q true damage conversion, whether to guarantee W off of E stun, positioning closer to walls to get faster E casts, etc.). That's a lot of complexity for one champion, and I'd guess if you had a strong grasp on everything _but_ the micromanagement of EQAAQ you'd be a very respectable Camille player, even if the micro is the most noticeable thing that separates unskilled Camille players from skilled ones. I don't think it's necessary to have perfect micro to be a competent Camille player, but as with any champion every mistake has a cost. Camille has a lot of opportunities to make mistakes and the cost for executing improperly is usually high for her, which is what makes her so difficult, but I don't think that means perfect micro is her baseline - she can function with some execution errors.
